sub_title: Associate Editor, climate change researcher and consultant
summary:
My expertise and major interest lie in:
- The development & application of participatory backcasting approaches for envisioning robust climate change adaptation futures (see Van Der Voorn et al., 2012; 2017)
- Combining backcasting and Systems Dynamics modelling for water-energy-food nexus studies
- The interplay of visions, paradigms and visionary frontrunners in historical transitions in water resources management (see Van der Voorn & Quist, 2018).
- Participatory & Integrated Climate Impact Assessment on water resources
- Designing & facilitating stakeholder-driven water management decision-making processes
- Global food, water & energy nexus (see my contribution to the 2013 UN World Economic and Social Survey)

I have several years of work experience in Bangladesh, India, South Africa, the United States, the United Kingdom, Hungary, Italy, Austria, Belgium, France, Spain, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands.

I published on the applicability of participatory backcasting for adaptive water management as well as on participatory approaches for community based drinking water supply in developing countries. I provided guest lectures on these topics at:
- University of Cape Town
- Bowie State University
- KTH Royal Institute of Technology
- Free University of Brussels (CrossTalks)
- UNESCO-IHE Institute for Water Education
- Delft University of Technology
- Erasmus University Rotterdam

I presented at various international conferences on water management.

I acted as journal reviewer for the following journals:
- Global Environmental Change
- Applied geography
- Futures
- Water Policy
- Journal of Climate Change Strategies and Management
- Journal of Mitigation and Adaptation of Strategies for Global Change
- Groundwater for Sustainable Development
- Resources
- Water
- Sustainability
- Hydrology

profile_positions.description:
I worked on the FRAMES project, aiming at increasing the resilience of areas and communities by working with the Multi-Layer Safety (MLS) Concept.

Climate change causes increasing sea levels and extreme rainfall patterns for areas in the North Sea Region. FRAMES (Flood Resilient Areas by multi-layEr Safety) aims on increasing the resilience of areas and communities by working with the Multi-Layer Safety (MLS) Concept. Traditional, static flood preventions,may not be sufficient anymore in the future. There will never be enough resources to protect every single citizen from flooding, but if we smartly combine resilience measures we can minimise impact. FRAMES shifts to Multi-Layer Safety smartly combining resilience measures. Frames aims at:

Flood resilient areas: improving infrastructure and spatial planning measures 

Flood resilient communities: making people and social stakeholders better prepared 

Flood resilient authorities: reducing recovery times and increase response capacity 

Partners form the UK, Denmark, Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands have designated 13 pilots in areas which are comparable from geographic and demographic view, so monitoring generates new insights and solutions.
